vocabulary.english: forgive me learners Nĩ ndĩrathiĩte karũtha kanini – I had gone for a short leave (rũtha – permission, also means leave). ‘ka’ before a word diminishes it to small so “karutha” is a small leave. Now that I am forgiven let’s proceed with today’s lesson. IRIO CIA MŨGIKŨYŨ – FOOD OF THE KIKUYU Note that this is just a lesson. Kikuyus today eat everything like everybody else. IRIO CIA RŨCIĨNĨ – FOOD OF THE MORNING (BREAKFAST) Cai kana ũcũrũ – tea or porridge Mũgate kana ngwacĩ – bread or sweet potato Ndũma kana mĩanga – Arrow root or cassava mũthigwiti - buiscuit; keki - cake IRIO CIA MŨTHENYA – FOOD FOR DAYTIME (LUNCH) Gĩtheri kana mũkimo – maize and beans (githeri) or mashed food (mukimo - usually bananas and any cereal with some greens). IRIO CIA HWAIĨNĨ – FOOD FOR THE EVENING Ngima kana mũcere – ugali (posho) or rice Cabaci kana ndũma na gĩtoero – chapatti or arrow root and stew (gitoero – any stew) Iria imata kana nyama na ngima – fermented milk or milk and ugali Kũmata – to ferment (also ‘to be foolish’) Kũgagata – to ferment, to be acidic (also to be sarcastic) Irio ciĩna cama – the food is tasty Irio ciĩna mūrīo – the food is sweet Irio ciĩna cumbī mũingi – the food has too much salt (cumbī mũingi) Cai nĩ mũcamũ cukari – the tea has enough sugar Gũcama – to taste, to have enough of whatever additive. MĪRUGĨRE – METHODS OF COOKING Gũtherũkia – to boil Gũkaranga – to fry Kũhĩhia – to roast IRIO INGĨ - OTHER FOODS Marigũ methĩ – raw bananas Marigũ meru – ripe bananas Gĩkwa - yam Mbembe - maize mboco - beans minji - peas https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=1301340073247047&set=pb.100063609806723.-2207520000 -----------

vocabulary.english: consonants g, h and k g (g) Guka gucia guoko gwaikwa - Grandfather, pull my hand Gĩra gĩkombe gĩkĩ - Come for this cup Gĩkombe h (h) Haha hena heho - This place is cold Huha mwaki wahota - Blow the fire if you can Hoho no ya hoha - the capsicum has shriveled k (k) Kaĩrĩtu kena karamu - the girl has a pen Karamu Kahĩĩ nĩ karatha kanyoni - The boy has shot the bird Kana kona kora kora - The child saw a frog and ran away Kiura - frog Kora - small frog
vocabulary.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

vocabulary.english: week 4 - 4 11. Ĩkũmi na ĩmwe - eleven 12. Ĩkũmi na ĩgĩrĩ - twelve 13. Ĩkũmi na ĩthatũ - thirteen We take a break from this progression and move on to number twenty. The archaic term for ten is "Mũrongo." It is used from number twenty onwards. 20. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ (literally two tens). 21. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ na ĩmwe, 22. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ na ĩgĩrĩĩ This goes on to 30. Mĩrongo ĩtatũ until we get to 99. Mĩrongo kenda na kenda The following are three digit numbers starting with 100. 100. Igana rĩmwe, 101. Igana rĩmwe na ĩmwe, 102. Igana rĩmwe na ĩgĩrĩĩ 120. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ - one hundred and twenty 141. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo ĩna na ĩmwe. 199. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo kenda na kenda. 1000. Ngiri ĩmwe - one thousand. For 'one million' we use a term borrowed from English - million 1000000. Mirioni ĩmwe - One million
vocabulary.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

vocabulary.english: t, th, ny t (t) tene O Na Tene na tene - forever and ever Tinia taama maita matano - cut the fabric five times Tara mbeca - count the money, tooria - accomplish, teta akũhe irio - complain so he/she gives you food, tunga karwĩmbo - compose a song th (th) thaani Thaani ĩno nĩ theru - this plate is clean Thooma ũtarĩ na itherũ - read without joking Thenga haha (ehera haha) - move away from here, thutha wa nyumba - behind the house, thooma ibuku rĩaku - read your book ny (ny) Nyanya Ruga Nyanya na nyeni - cook tomatoes and greens Mũrarũ nĩ Nyoka - Mũrarũ is a snake Nyamũ cia gĩthaka - wild animals, nyeni nĩ njega - vegetables are good, Nyenje ĩ gĩko - a cockroach is dirty
vocabulary.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

vocabulary.kikuyu: This image is an excellent guide for learning some key aspects of Kikuyu pronunciation. ## Kikuyu Pronunciation Guide The word at the top, **Nĩtwĩrĩririkanie**, means **"Let us remember"** (literally: "remind ourselves"). The guide then provides phonetic examples for the key vowels and a couple of consonants: ### Vowels Kikuyu has seven cardinal vowels, some of which are marked with a tilde (~), a diaeresis (¨), or an acute accent (´) in other texts to show the two different degrees of openness for the same sound. This guide uses the tilde to distinguish them.

vocabulary.english: This is a **bilabial fricative**. It's not the hard English 'B'. Instead, it's a soft sound made by bringing both lips close together and forcing the air through, often sounding like a **soft 'V'** or sometimes like 'W'.
vocabulary.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

vocabulary.english: Note: The English example for **B** (**mahaBharat**) is pointing out the softer, aspirated /bh/ sound found in some Indic languages, which is closer to the softer Kikuyu sound than the hard English 'B'.
vocabulary.kikuyu: Pronounced as the **'ch'** in **ch**air or the **'sh'** in **sh**oe, but often somewhere in between. It is usually represented as **/ʃ/** or **/tʃ/**.
vocabulary.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

vocabulary.kikuyu: The image provides a vocabulary list for the major organs of the human **digestive system** in Kikuyu. The title, **Ciĩga cia njĩra ya irio**, translates to: * **Ciĩga** means **parts** or **organs**. * **cia** means **of the**. * **njĩra** means **way** or **path**. * **ya** means **of**. * **irio** means **food**. * So, **Ciĩga cia njĩra ya irio** literally means **"The parts of the path of food"** or **"The digestive system."** --- ## Kikuyu Digestive System Vocabulary Here are the Kikuyu terms for the organs labeled in the diagram:

vocabulary.english: Kim Ole Kimanĩ** 1. **Kĩero**... **Thigh** 2. **Cĩerĩo**.... **Thighs** 3. **Wambũĩ mĩcore**....**Zebra** 4. **Ĩhoerõ**.... **Church** 5. **Ĩhererĩo**.... **Hell** **(Names listed in the image: Edu Njeru, Jeremy Ng'ang'a, Kim Ole Kimanĩ, George Fenzy, John Gathatwa)** (The watermark at the bottom reads: "Learn Kikuyu - Wĩrute Gĩkũyũ - Jĩfunze Kikuyu") *** ## 2. Transcription of image\_adf029.jpg (Verb: Aka) **(The text is set against a tan background, bordered by African-style animal prints.)** * **Wagatano - Friday** * **Verb - Aka** * **Aka** - **build** * **Gũaka** - **to build** * **Gũaka nyũmba** - **to build a house** * **Mwakĩre nyũmba** - **build for him/her ...** * **Aka** - **build**; **Akai** - **Build (you all)** * **Mwako** - **a building**; **(A watermark diagonally across the text reads: "Learn Kikuyu - Wĩrute Gĩkũyũ")
vocabulary.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

vocabulary.english: Saturday** ## conditional tense * **Menya** - know; **Kũmeya** - to know * **ũngĩ** + **menya** - If you know (find out) * **Ũngĩmenya ũngĩka atĩa?** - If you knew, what would you do? * **ingĩ** + **menya** - If I know (find out) * **Ingĩmenya no thĩĩ gwitũ** - If I know (found out) I would go home * **Ingĩmenya kwandĩka no nyandĩke marũa** --- Would you like me to translate the last Kikuyu sentence for you?

(We started ten minutes ago.) | **Two**kĩra | | **2nd Person** (You Sg./You Pl.) | Wo- | Mwo- | **Wokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (You started ten minutes ago.) | **Wo**kĩra | | | | | **Mwokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (You all started ten minutes ago.) | **Mwo**kĩra | | **3rd Person** (He/She/They) | O- | Mo- | **Okĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (He/She started ten minutes ago.) | **O**kĩra | | | | | **Mokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (They started ten minutes ago.) | **Mo**kĩra | --- ### Past Tense

conjugations.kikuyu: Nda/ Nda | | **hand** | Rũhĩ/ Hĩ | | **waist** | Njohero/ Njohero | | **knee** | Îru/ Maru | | **fingers** | Kĩara/ Twara | | **leg** | Kũgũrũ/ Magũrũ | | **foot** | Ikĩnya/ Makĩnya | | **toes** | Kĩara/ Twara | *** ## Nuclear Family and Dialogue This vocabulary and dialogue are taken from the image illustrating the family: | Kikuyu Phrase | English Translation | Context/Notes | |:---|:---|:---| | **Ũyũ nĩ baba** | This is father | Father is taking photographs. | | **Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ** | This other one is mother | | | **Tũrũgamĩte na mwarĩ wa maitũ** | We are standing with my sister | Literally: "We are standing with the daughter of my mother." | | **Ũcio mũraihu nĩ mama** | The tall one is my uncle (mother's side) | **Mama** refers to the maternal uncle. | | **Baba arahũra mbica** | Father is taking photographs | | | **Mwarimũ:** Maina rũgama | **Teacher:** Maina, stand up | | | **Maina:** Nĩ ndarũgama mwarimũ | **Maina:** I have stood up teacher | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ nũũ ? | **Teacher:** Who is this | Asking about the father. | | **Maina:** Ũyũ nĩ baba | **Maina:** This is father | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ nũũ ? | **Teacher:** Who is this other one? | Asking about the mother. | | **Maina:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ | **Maina:** This other one is mother | | | **Mwarimũ:** Mũrũgamĩte naũ? | **Teacher:** Who are you standing with? | | | **Maina:** Tũrũgamĩte na Mwarĩ wa maitũ | **Maina:** We are standing with my sister | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ĩkara thĩ | **Teacher:** Sit down | | *** *The vertical text on both images reads: **Learn Kikuyu

conjugations.kikuyu: Nda/ Nda | | **hand** | Rũhĩ/ Hĩ | | **waist** | Njohero/ Njohero | | **knee** | Îru/ Maru | | **fingers** | Kĩara/ Twara | | **leg** | Kũgũrũ/ Magũrũ | | **foot** | Ikĩnya/ Makĩnya | | **toes** | Kĩara/ Twara | *** ## 2. Health and Hospital Phrases This section provides vocabulary and common phrases related to illness and visiting a hospital (**Thibitarĩ**). ### Vocabulary | Kikuyu Term | English Meaning | Image Context | |:---|:---|:---| | **Thibitarĩ** | Hospital | Building exterior | | **Mũrwaru** | Patient / Sick person | Person on a hospital bed | | **Ndagĩtarĩ** | Doctor (male) | Man in a lab coat | | **Mũrigitani** | Doctor (female/general term) | Woman in a lab coat | | **Dagĩtarĩ wa magego** | Dentist | Person sitting in a dental chair | | **Mĩthaiga** | Medicine / Drugs | Pills and bottles | | **Ndawa** | Medicine / Remedy | Pills and bottles | ### Dialogue and Phrases | Kikuyu Phrase | English Translation | |:---|:---| | **Ndĩ mũrwaru** | I am sick | | **Ndiraiguia wega** | I am not feeling well | | **Thĩĩ thibitarĩ** | Go to the hospital | | **Ũraatũũrwo nĩ kũ?** | Where are you hurting (where is your pain)? | | **Ndiraatũũrwo nĩ mũtwee** | I have a headache | | **Nĩ ũraatũũrwo nĩ nda?** | Do you have a stomachache? | | **Aca ndiraatũũrwo nĩ nda** | No I do not have a stomachache | | **Ũraatũũrwo nĩ kũũ ũngĩ?** | Where else are you hurting? | | **O na igego nĩ rĩraatũũra** | I also have a toothache | | **Thĩĩ wone ndagĩtarĩ wa magego** | Go see a dentist | | **Eha mũrigitanĩ** | Where is the nurse? | | **Amba ũthĩmwo ratirĩ** | Get your weight checked first | | **Hĩĩ! Wĩ na ũrugarĩ!** | Wah! Your temperature is high | *** *The vertical text on both images reads: **Learn Kikuyu

conjugations.kikuyu: Ndirica ya keerĩ** | The second window | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Cabi ya gatatũ** | The third cap | **ya** (for Cĩ- / N- class nouns) | | **Metha ya kana** | The fourth table | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Nyoni ya gatano** | The fifth bird | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **thamaki ya gatandatũ** | The sixth fish | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Ibuku rĩa mũgwanja** | The seventh book | **rĩa** (for Rĩ- / Ma- class nouns) | | **Itimũ rĩa kanana** | The eighth spear | **rĩa** (for Rĩ- / Ma- class nouns) | | **Icembe rĩa Kenda** | The ninth hoe | **rĩa** (for Rĩ- / Ma- class nouns) | | **Mbaathi ya Ikũmi** | The tenth bus | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Gĩkombe kĩa mbere** | The first cup | **kĩa** (for Gĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Ngirathi ya keerĩ** | The second glass | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Gĩciko gĩa gatatũ** | The third spoon | **gĩa** (for Gĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Mũbira wa kana** | The fourth ball | **wa** (for Mũ- / Mĩ- class nouns) | | **Nyũmba ya gatano** | The fifth house | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Kĩratũ gĩa gatandatũ** | The sixth shoe | **gĩa** (for Kĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Karamu ka mũgwanja** | The seventh pen (or *small pen*) | **ka** (for Ka- / Tũ- class nouns) | | **Gĩtĩ gĩa kanana** | The eighth chair | **gĩa** (for Gĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Mũĩrĩtu wa Kenda** | The ninth girl | **wa** (for Mũ- / A- class nouns) | | **thaani ya Ikũmi** | The tenth plate | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | *** **Learn Kĩkũyũ

conjugations.kikuyu: Ndigũkwĩra ũrĩa njĩtagwo** | I will not tell you my name | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-gũ...*) | | **Nĩ waragia Gĩkũyũ?** | Do you speak Kĩkũyũ? | Question (Present Tense) | | **Ndiaragia Gĩkũyũ o na hanini** | I don't speak Kĩkũyũ (even a little) | 1st Person Singular Present Negative (*Ndi-a...*) | | **Mũgai nĩ aragia Gĩkũyũ?** | Does Mũgai speak...? | Question (Present Tense) | | **Mũgai ndaragia Gĩkũyũ** | Mũgai does not speak Kĩkũyũ | 3rd Person Singular Present Negative (*Nda-ra...*) | | **O na Gĩthweri tũtĩaragia** | Even Swahili we do not speak (We also don't speak Swahili) | 1st Person Plural Present Negative (*Tũ-tĩ-a...*) | | **Aria kahora** | Speak slowly | Positive imperative (Command) | | **Ndĩkwaria kahora** | I will not speak slowly | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-kũ...*) | | **Tũtĩkwaria Kahora** | We will not speak slowly | 1st Person Plural Future Negative (*Tũ-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **Atĩ mũtĩkwaria kahora?** | So you will not ......? (So you all will not speak slowly?) | 2nd Person Plural Future Negative Question (*Mũ-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **Moiga matĩkwaria kahora** | They have said they will not speak slowly | 3rd Person Plural Future Negative (*Ma-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **O na wee ndũkwaria kahora?** | Even you, you will not speak slowly? | 2nd Person Singular Future Negative Question (*Ndũ-kũ...*) | | **Thĩĩ mũciĩ na ihenya** | Go home fast (Quickly) | Positive imperative (Command) | | **Ndigũthĩĩ** | I will not go. | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-gũ...*) | *** **Learn Kĩkũyũ

conjugations.english: Nyita kanua ũgĩathĩmũra | To sneeze. Cover your mouth when sneezing. | | **Gũkomba** - ũrakomba mũndũ nĩkĩ? | To make bad gestures/to borrow. Why are you making a bad gesture at a person? | | **Kũigua Kĩnyiria** - Araigua kĩnyĩria ona ndinĩhoho | To be disgusted/nauseated. He/She feels disgusted even though he/she is not drunk. | | **Kũnyĩra** - Maranyĩra irio cia mũcaina | To express disgust for food. They are expressing disgust for the Chinese food. | | **Kũnunũha** - Ndanunũha, ndakoma na ngara | To nose bleed. He has a nosebleed, he is sleeping on a sheet/mat. | | **Gũĩthĩkĩra** - Aigua mũndũ akua, ethĩkĩra | To have a sad posture/to mourn. He/She hears a person has died, he/she sits sadly. | | **Gwĩthĩkĩra nĩũndũ wa kĩeha kĩingĩ** | To have a sad posture due to much sorrow. | --- ## Verb Conjugation Exercise To fulfill the instruction, we will conjugate the verb stems into the **Past Tense

conjugations.kikuyu: Ndigiri ĩno nĩ ya Wajir** * **Translation:** This donkey is from Wajir; It is found in Wajir; it belongs to Wajir. * **Nĩmũrona ũrĩa ĩmenye-reirwo do you (all) see** * **Translation:** Do you (all) see how it has been taken care of? --- ### Key Vocabulary and Grammar | Kikuyu Word/Phrase | Literal Meaning/Grammar Note | | :--- | :--- | | **Ndigiri** | **Donkey** (The authentic Kikuyu word; *Bunda* or *Ng'unda* are also used by some people) | | **Ĩno** | **This one** (Demonstrative for noun class N/N $\rightarrow$ **ici** is the plural: **These ones**) | | **Nĩ ũrona?** | **Can you see? Do you see?** (Singular) | | **Nĩmũrona** | **Do you (all) see** (Plural) | | **Ũrĩa** | **How** (In this context only) | | **Nĩ ũrona ũrĩa...** | **Do you see how....** | | **Kũmenyerera** | **to take care** | | **Menyerera** | **take care of** | | **Ũrĩa ĩmenyerereirwo** | **how it has been cared for** (Uses the passive voice **-irwo**) | | **Wimenyerere** | **take care of yourself** (Uses the reflexive prefix **-i-**) | | **Wega** | **well; good** | | **Oha** | **tie** | | **Mĩohe** | **tie it** (Command) | | **Ohetwo** | **he has been tied** (Passive voice) | | **Yohetwo** | **it has been tied** (Passive voice, applied to the donkey, which falls under the $\text{I

proverbs.kikuyu: Around your sitting room.** | Kikuyu Word | English Word | | :--- | :--- | | **Mũrango** | Door | | **Kabati** | Cupboard | | **Metha** | Table | | **Nđirica** | Window | | **Gĩtĩ** | Chair | | **Gaturwa / Njĩngwa** | Stool | --- ## Text from Image 2: Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi (Kikuyu Creation Story) **Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi** **Aciari a rũrĩrĩ rwa Gĩkũyũ nĩ a ?** Who are the parents of the kikuyu tribe? **Aciari a rũrĩrĩ rwa Gĩkũyũ nĩ Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi** The parents of the Kikuyu are Gĩkũyũ and Mũũmbi **Maarĩ na ciana cigana?** How many children did they have? **Marĩ na ciana kenda** They had nine children. **Kenda mũiyũrũ** - the full nine (ten) **Tũhĩĩ kana tũirĩtu?** Girls or boys? **Tũirĩtu** - Girls. | Kikuyu Word | English Meaning | | :--- | :--- | | **Rũrĩrĩ** | a community speaking one language | | **Nyũmba** | house (traditionally woman's hut) | | **Thingira** | hut (traditionally for men) | | **Ikũmbĩ** | granary | | **Mũgũnda** | garden, farm. **Gĩcagi** - a village | --- ## Text from Image 3: Jobs **Jobs** **(Nĩĩ) Nđĩ bundi** - I am a handyman (carpenter, plumber etc.) **Nđutaga wĩra wa mbaũ** - I work with timber **. (Wee) wĩ mũrĩmi** - You are a farmer **Ũrutaga wĩra wa mũgũnda** - You work in a farm **. (We) nĩ ndereba** - he/she is a driver **. (Inyuĩ) mwĩ atongoria** - You (plural) are leaders **Mũrutaga wĩra wa gũtongoria anđũ** - your job is to lead people **. (O) nĩ borithi** - they are police (men/women) **Marutaga wĩra wa kũũnĩtĩa anđũ** - their work is to arrest people **. Ũyũ nĩ mũũbĩa** - this is a priest (catholic) **Arutaga wĩra wa gũtongoria magongona ma kanitha** - His work is to lead church services 1. **(Nĩĩ) Nđĩ mũhũrĩri wa mbica** - I am a photographer 2. **(Wee) wĩ mũgwĩmi** - You are a hunter 3. **(We) nĩ mũrĩithia wa mahiũ** - he/she is a herder (of domestic animals) 4. **(Inyũĩ) mwĩ aturi** - You are iron mongers 5. **(O) nĩ ombi a nyũngũ** - they are potters (lit. molders of pots) 6. **Ũyũ nĩ mũgo** - This is a medicine (person) **Write sentences in Kikuyu to say what Numbes 1. to 6. do. proverbs.kikuyu: You've uploaded several images containing Kikuyu language lessons, covering vocabulary, grammar, and sentence structure. Here is a compilation and synthesis of the information presented in those images. *** ## 1. Grammar: Future Tenses (Second Person Singular) The images illustrate the **Second Person Singular** (you) future tense, which has different prefixes depending on the time frame. ### ⏳ A Few Moments Later or Anytime Today The prefixes used for actions happening soon are **Ûgû-, Ûgwî-, Ûkwî-,** and **Ûkû-**. | Example | Translation | Prefix | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Ûgûkîra** dagîka ikûmi ciathira. | You will wake up after ten minutes. | Ûgû- | | **Ûgwîthamba** na maî mahoro. | You will take a bath with cold water. | Ûgwî- | | **Ûkwîhumba** nguo naihenya. | You will put on your clothes quickly. | Ûkwî- | ### 🗓️ Anytime Tomorrow and Into the Future The prefixes used for actions happening tomorrow or beyond are **Ûgo-, Ûge-, Ûke-,** and **Ûga-**. | Example | Translation | Prefix | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Ûgokîra** dagîka ikûmi ciathira. | You will wake up ten after ten minutes. | Ûgo- | | **Ûgethamba** na maî mahoro. | You will take a bath with cold water. | Ûge- | | **Ûkehumba** nguo naihenya. | You will put on your clothes quickly. | Ûke- | | **Ûkaruga** caî. | You will make tea. | Ûka- | *** ## 2. Vocabulary: Types of Houses (*Mîthemba ya Nyûmba*) The lessons cover three main types of traditional and modern houses, focusing on construction materials. | Type of House | Kikuyu Term | Construction Material | Roofing Material | Other Feature | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Stone House** | **Nyûmba ya Mahiga** | **Mahiga** (stones) | **Mabati** (iron sheets) | **Rûthingo rwa mahiga** (stone wall) | | **Timber House** | **Nyûmba ya mbaû** | **Mbaû** (timber/wood) | **Maturubarĩ** (tiles) | **Rûthingo rwa mbaû** (wooden wall) | | **Mud Hut** | **Nyûmba ya ndooro** | **Ndooro** (mud) | **Nyeki** (grass) or **ithanjĩ** (reeds) | **Rûthingo rwa ndooro** (mud wall) | *** ## 3. Vocabulary: Fauna and Weather ### 🐾 Insects (*Tûnyamû tûnyinyi*) | Kikuyu | English | Notes | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Mûthûa** | Termite | | | **Thûraku** | Soldier ant | Moves in a line. | | **Thigiriri** | Black ant | Small black ants. | | **Mûgagaca** | Fire ant | Very tiny brown ants that move in large groups. | ### 🐦 Birds (*Nyoni*) | Kikuyu | Scientific Name | English Name | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Kanyua njui** | *Cinnyris mediocris* | Sunbird | | **Gĩchorogothu** | *Pycnonotus barbatus* | Common bulbul | | **Ngũgũ** | *Tauraco hartlaubi* | Hartlaub's Turaco | ### ⛈️ Weather and Seasons (*Hîndî ya Mbura na ya riua*) | Kikuyu | English | Notes | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Rûheni** | Lightening | Comes before **marurumĩ** (thunder). | | **Mbura nî ya ringa** | The rain has started | Literally: 'the rain has beaten'. | | **Nî kûrathuthua** | It is drizzling | | | **Ime** | Dew | | | **Matu ma mbura** | Rain clouds | The grey ones. | | **Rûkûngû** | Dust | | | **Kigûû** | Flash flood | This word means *water* in Kikamba. | | **Thano** | Very dry season | | | **Mûkûnga mbura** | Rainbow | | | **Kwîna kibii** | There is fog | | *** ## 4. Grammar: Kikuyu Pronoun Table The image provides an overview of various pronouns and their variations due to noun class. | Category | Singular | Plural | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **I, me, myself** | **Nîî** | **(We, ourself) ithuî** | | **You** | **Wëë** | **Inyuî** | | **He, she** | **Wë** | **(Them) O** | | **mine** | Wakwa, Gĩakwa, gakwa, yakwa, rĩakwa | Ciakwa, Akwa, Makwa, twakwa | | **yours** | Gĩaku, gaku, yaku, waku, rĩaku | Ciaku, Twaku, ma-ku, aku | | **His/hers** | Gĩake, gake, yake, wake, rĩake | Ciake, Twake, make, ake | | **Theirs'** | Kĩao, kao, yao, rĩao, wao | Cĩao, Twao, mao, ao | | **it** | Kĩo, ko, yo, guo, rĩo | Cĩo, yo, mo, o | | **Who?** | **Ûû?** | **A?** | | **Anybody** | **Mûndû o wothe** | **Andû o

proverbs.kikuyu: Extracted Text from Images Here is the text extracted from the images you provided: --- ### Image 1: Kikuyu Creation Story (Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi) **Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi** **Aciari a rũrĩrĩ rwa Gĩkũyũ nĩ a ?** Who are the parents of the kikuyu tribe? **Aciari a rũrĩrĩ rwa Gĩkũyũ nĩ Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi** The parents of the Kikuyu are Gĩkũyũ and Mũũmbi **Maarĩ na ciana cigana?** How many children did they have? **Marĩ na ciana kenda** They had nine children. **Kenda mũiyũrũ** - the full nine (ten) **Tũhĩĩ kana tũirĩtu?** Girls or boys? **Tũirĩtu** - Girls. **Rũrĩrĩ** - a community speaking one language **Nyũmba** - house (traditionally woman's hut) **Thingira** - hut (traditionally for men) **Ikũmbĩ** - granary **Mũgũnda** - garden, farm. **Gĩcagi** - a village --- ### Image 2: Jobs (Wĩra) **Jobs** **(Nĩĩ) Nđĩ bundi** - I am a handyman (carpenter, plumber etc.) **Nđutaga wĩra wa mbaũ** - I work with timber **. (Wee) wĩ mũrĩmi** - You are a farmer **Ũrutaga wĩra wa mũgũnda** - You work in a farm **. (We) nĩ ndereba** - he/she is a driver **. (Inyuĩ) mwĩ atongoria** - You (plural) are leaders **Mũrutaga wĩra wa gũtongoria anđũ** - your job is to lead people **. (O) nĩ borithi** - they are police (men/women) **Marutaga wĩra wa kũũnĩtĩa anđũ** - their work is to arrest people **. Ũyũ nĩ mũũbĩa** - this is a priest (catholic) **Arutaga wĩra wa gũtongoria magongona ma kanitha** - His work is to lead church services 1. **(Nĩĩ) Nđĩ mũhũrĩri wa mbica** - I am a photographer 2. **(Wee) wĩ mũgwĩmi** - You are a hunter 3. **(We) nĩ mũrĩithia wa mahiũ** - he/she is a herder (of domestic animals) 4. **(Inyũĩ) mwĩ aturi** - You are iron mongers 5. **(O) nĩ ombi a nyũngũ** - they are potters (lit. molders of pots) 6. **Ũyũ nĩ mũgo** - This is a medicine (person) **Write sentences in Kikuyu to say what Numbes 1. to 6. do. Use the following verbs - 1. Kũhũra mbica, 2. kũgwĩma, 3. Kũrĩithia, 4. gũtura, 5. kũũmba, 6. kũragũra (Example: arutaga wĩra wa kũragũra)** --- ### Image 3: Polite Term for Snake **Nyamũ ya thĩ** - a polite way of refering to a **snake** (to avoid attracting it to your house). --- ### Image 4: Counting and Birds **Mbata** - Duck **Ngũkũ ya mwera** - Hen **Gacui** - chick **Ngũkũ ya njamba** - Cock --- ### Image 5: Some Verbs **Some Verbs that you should know** **Gũcaria** - to search **Gũcoka** - to return, to come back (person) **Gũcokia** - to return (an object) **Gũĩka** - To do **Gũikara** - to stay **Gũikara thĩ** - to sit down **Gũikena** - To be happy **Gũkinya** - To arrive, to step on **Gũthambia** - to wash **Gũthĩĩ rũgendo** - To go on a journey **Gũthũkia** - To damage, to spoil **Gũtigara** - to remain **Gũtinia** - to cut **Gweterera** - To wait **Gwĩcĩrĩria** - to think, to reason **Kũgeria** - to try --- ### Image 6: Family Terms (Nuclear and Extended) **Nuclear family** **Baba** - father **Maitũ** - Mother **Mũrũ wa maitũ** - Brother **Mwarĩ wa maitũ** - Sister **Mũrũ wa baba** - Half Brother **Mwarĩ wa baba** - Half Sister **Extended family** **Guka** - Grandfather (Muranga/Kiambu Kikuyu) **Wagũi** - Grandfather (Nyeri Kikuyu) **Cũcũ** - Grandmother **Tata** - Aunt **Mama** - Uncle (Mother's side) **Baba mũnini** - Uncle (Father's younger brother) **Baba mũkũrũ** - Uncle (Father's older brother) **Mũrũ wa tata** - Cousin **Mũrũ wa mama** - Cousin **NOTE**: All your Father's brothers' wives are adressed as "**mother**" **Thooma na ũnyite mũgambo** - read and record --- ### Image 7: Conversation about Family **Nuclear Family** **Ũyũ nĩ baba** - this is father **Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ** - this other one is mother **Tũrũgamĩte na mwarĩ wa maitũ** - We are standing with my sister **Ũcio mũraihu nĩ mama** - the tall one is my uncle (mother's side) **Baba arahũra mbica** - Father is taking photographs **Mwarimũ:** Maina rũgama Maina, stand up **Maina:** Nĩ nđarũgama Mwarimũ **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ nũũ ? Who is this **Maina:** Ũyũ nĩ baba **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ nũũ ? **Maina:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ **Mwarimũ:** Mũrũgamĩte naũ? **Maina:** Tũrũgamĩte na Mwarĩ wa maitũ **Mwarimũ:** ĩkara thĩ Sit down --- ### Image 8: Cold Days (Mĩthenya ya heho) **Mĩthenya ya heho - cold days** 1. **Hĩ! proverbs.kikuyu: The image provides a list of Kikuyu words that end in **-go** and their English translations. Here is the breakdown of the list: | Kikuyu Word | English Translation | | :--- | :--- | | **Gĩcĩgo** | area | | **Igego** | tooth | | **Iyego** | a village in Murang'a | | **Kĩugo** | word | | **Mbogo** | buffalo | | **Mũgogo** | log | | **Mũndũ mũgo** | diviner / traditional healer | | **Mũrĩgo** | luggage | | **Mũtego** | trap | | **Mũtũgo** | habit | | **Ndoogo** | smoke | ### Additional Words/Names (Unformatted List on the Right) The right side of the image appears to be a list of user submissions or additional words, but some are incomplete or repeated: * **Mugo** (Diviner) - Likely a repetition of *Mũndũ mũgo* * **Kĩugo** (Word) - Repetition * **Kĩogo** (Head) - (Note: The common word for head is *kĩongo* or *mutwe*) * **Ĩgego** (Tooth) - Repetition * **Magego** (Teeth) - Plural of *Igego* * **Mbogo** (Buffalo) - Repetition * **Mitugo** (Behavior) - Plural

proverbs.kikuyu: This looks like a great way to start learning **Kikuyu**! Combining the words you have here is a perfect exercise. Here are ten simple sentences formed by combining the verbs and nouns from your image: ## Simple Kikuyu Sentences 🇰🇪 1. **Ũka haha.** $\rightarrow$ Come here. 2. **Andĩka marũa.** $\rightarrow$ Write a letter. 3. **Rĩra maĩ.** $\rightarrow$ Cry for water. (This could also mean "Cry water," depending on context, but "cry for water" is a common simple expression). 4. **Theka mũthũuri.** $\rightarrow$ Laugh at the man. 5. **Rĩa irio.** $\rightarrow$ Eat food. 6. **Aria na mwanake.** $\rightarrow$ Speak with the young man. 7. **Thii wĩra.** $\rightarrow$ Go to work. 8. **Thooma marũa.** $\rightarrow$ Read a letter. 9. **Ruga ũcũrũ.** $\rightarrow$ Cook porridge. 10. **Mũirĩtu aruta wĩra.** $\rightarrow$ The girl is doing work. (Literally: Girl remove/do work). --- ### A Few Bonus Sentences! ✨ Here are a few more using the remaining words for extra practice: * **Kira, mũtumia.** $\rightarrow$ Keep quiet, woman. * **Ruta irio.** $\rightarrow$ Remove the food. * **Mũthũuri arĩa irio.** $\rightarrow$ The man is eating food. Let me know if you'd like to try translating any of those sentences back into English or if you have another list of words you'd like to work

proverbs.kikuyu: Here is the transcription of the text in the image: **Mũthenya Wakana** - **Thursday** (Image of four young girls) Picture courtesy of [www.pixabay.com](https://www.pixabay.com) **Tũirĩtu tũna** - **Four (small) girls** **Aĩrĩtu ana** - **Four girls** **Mũirĩtu ũmwe nĩ akĩndĩtwo njuĩrĩ** - **One of the girls has plaited hair** **Aĩrĩtu aya nĩ maratheka** - **These girls are laughing** **Kairĩtu kamwe kena kĩng'ũru** - **One of the girls has bare gums (teeth removed)** **Twana tũtũ** - **These (small) children** **Ciana ici** - **These children** **Tũirĩtu tũtũ** - **These (small) children** **Aĩrĩtu aya nĩ akũ?** - **where are these girls from?** **tũirĩtu tũtũ nĩ twa bũrũri ũrĩkũ?** - **which country are these girls from?** --- The partial text on the bottom right

proverbs.english: and Phrases ### Wakana – Thursday * **Ikarĩra gĩtĩ** - Sit on a chair * **Rũgama gĩtĩ igũrũ** - Stand on top of a chair * **Koma urĩrĩnĩ** - Sleep on a bed * **Koma na nda** - Sleep on your belly * **Koma na mũgongo** - Sleep on your back * **Ũka methainĩ** - come to the table * **Igĩrĩra irio methainĩ** - Put the food on the table * **Tonya nyũmba** - Enter the house * **Uma Nyũmba** - Go out of the house * **Uma nja** - Go out --- ### Important Note on "Outside" In Kikuyu, **"outside" is a place you can go or come out of. Therefore, Uma nja can also mean "Come from outside

proverbs.kikuyu: Here is the transcription and translation of the Kikuyu story titled "Karũgano ka Wambũi Mĩcore na Njogu" (Story of Zebra and Elephant), presented in plain text: *** ## Transcription and Translation: Story of Zebra and Elephant **Karũgano ka Wambũi Mĩcore na Njogu** - **Translation** **Story of Zebra and Elephant** * **Wambũi Mĩcore** - **Zebra** * **yarĩ ĩmwe ya nyamũ** - **was one of the animals** * **irĩa ciarĩ thaka mũno** - **that were most beautiful** * **bũrũriinĩ wa nyamũ** - **in the country of animals** * **Yarĩ na rũũa rũthaka** - **it had a beautiful hide (skin)** * **rwa mĩkarara mĩerũ na mĩirũ** - **with black and white stripes** * **Nyamũ ciothe** - **all the animals** * **ciamĩroragĩra ĩgegete mũno** - **looked at (Zebra) in awe** * **Nyamũ cionaga** - **the animals saw** * **ĩrĩ ya mathekania mũno** - **as very funny** * **Yatũmaga matheke** - **it made them laugh** * **kinya makoma mbaru** - **until their ribs ached (hardened)** * **Mamĩũragia atĩrĩrĩ** - **They used to ask it...** * **Mĩcore, ũhũraga thũ cĩaku atĩa?** - **Striped one, how do you fight your enemies?** * **Mĩcore yarũgamaga** - **The striped one would stand** * **na magũrũ ma mbere** - **with the forelegs** * **ĩgaikĩia mateke** - **and kicked** * **na magũrũ ma thutha** - **with the rear legs** * **Nyamũ ciothe** - **all the animals** * **cĩagũagĩa na mũtheko** - **fell down laughing (broke into laughter)** * **Hĩtĩ nĩyo yathekaga** - **hyena is the one that laughed** * **na mũgambo mũnene** - **in a loud voice** * **gũkĩra nyamũ irĩa ingĩ** - **than all the other animals** * **O na ũmũthĩ** - **even today** * **hĩtĩ yarĩrikana** - **when hyena remembers** * **ũrĩa Wambũi Mĩcore** - **how the zebra** * **ĩrũaga** - **fights** * **ĩthekaga ĩrĩ ĩkĩ ũtuko** - **it laughs alone in the night** (A faded watermark vertically on the right side
